Fig 13 Screening of single-atom catalysts of transition metal supported on MoSe2 for high-efficiency nitrogen reduction reaction Pengfei Hou Conceptualization Methodology Software Writing – original draft a Yuhong Huang Resources Supervision a ⁎ Fei Ma Funding acquisition b Gangqiang Zhu Supervision a Ruhai Du Formal analysis a Xiumei Wei Formal analysis a Jianmin Zhang Project administration a Min Wang Validation a a School of Physics & Information Technology, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, Shaanxi, China School of Physics & Information Technology Shaanxi Normal University Xi'an Shaanxi 710119 China aSchool of Physics & Information Technology, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, Shaanxi, China b State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Behavior of Materials, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, Shaanxi, China State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Behavior of Materials Xi'an Jiaotong University Xi'an Shaanxi 710049 China bState Key Laboratory for Mechanical Behavior of Materials, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, Shaanxi, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Two-dimensional single-atom catalysts (2D SACs) have attracted much more attention in the field of ammonia synthesis via electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR). In this work, we comprehensively study the NRR performance of 28 transition metals SACs loaded on 2D MoSe2 using density functional theory calculations. In view of thermodynamics and electrochemical stability, adsorption of N2, selectivity and activity of NRR, Mn, Os, V@MoSe2 exhibit outstanding performances with the most favorable potentials of -0.39 V, -0.36 V and -0.36 V, respectively. The excellent NRR performances are comprehensively related to the electronic states, kinetics, and NN bond length. Furthermore, aiming at three vital processes of NRR (adsorption and activation of N2, adsorption strength of intermediates, and the limiting potential), three independent descriptors (φ, ICOHP, Δ G * N ) are adopted to make the activity trend clear. The results are of guiding significance to the design of high-efficiency NRR using SAC. Graphical abstract A comprehensive screening process picks out Mn, Os, V@MoSe2 as potential NRR candidates. Multiple descriptors build a panoramic picture of NRR. Image, graphical abstract Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is an indispensable feedstock for fertilizers, plastics and pharmaceuticals, and is widely used in industries and agriculture [1–3]. Due to the harsh condition required to break the strong NN bond in Haber-Bosch (H-B) process, industrial synthetic NH3 consumes a tremendous amount of fossil fuels [4–6]. It's exciting that electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) provides a possibility to synthesize NH3 under ambient conditions, which is a promising way to substitute the energy-intensive H-B process. In recent years, due to the high utilization efficiency of noble metals and excellent catalytic activity [7,8], the application of single-atom catalysts (SAC) in many important catalytic reactions (NRR, OER/ORR, CO2RR, HER, etc.) has aroused the extensive interest of researchers [9–14]. Because the electronic metal-support interactions (EMSI) play an important role in SAC [15], a single atom and its surrounding coordination environment, rather than the single atom itself, is deemed as the real active center in catalytic reactions. Two-dimensional (2D) materials, such as, modified graphene [16,17] g-CN [18–23], GaN [24], h-BN [25,26], BP [27,28] and MXenes [29,30], et al. [31–33], have been demonstrated to be excellent substrates anchoring transition metal (TM) atoms. SACs anchored on 2D transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have been widely studied for electrochemical NRR. Chen et al. predicted that Cr@WS2, Tc@WS2 and Os@WS2 SACs could efficiently convert N2 into NH3 with favorable limiting potentials of −0.37 V, −0.27 V and −0.33 V, respectively [34]. Cai et al. demonstrated that Ru@PtS2 has effective activation on N2 and the low reaction barrier in NRR [35]. Zhao et al. found that Fe@MoS2 exhibits superior catalytic activity for NRR with an average production rate of NH3 of 12.5 μg·h−1·cm−2 and a high faradaic efficiency of 10.8% at −0.1 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) at ambient conditions [36]. Guo et al. performed theoretical screening and found that Ti-decorated MoS2 was an excellent NRR electrocatalyst with a favorable limiting potential of −0.63 V [37]. Two-dimensional MoSe2 as another typical TMD material has also been widely studied [38–40]. Compared with MoS2, which has been extensively studied, the main advantage of MoSe2 is a higher electrical conductivity as Se brings its intrinsic metallic nature (1 × 10−3 S/m for Se vs. 5 × 10−28 S/m for S) [41–43]. Owing to the substantial role of Mo in forming a metallic nature, MoSe2 can be considered one of the best TMD having a metallic nature, which is of utmost importance in electrochemical applications. Can single atom be anchored on monolayer MoSe2 with high NRR selectivity and activity? Is it possible to propose a set of universal descriptors to rapidly predict and evaluate the NRR activity of TM@MoSe2 SACs? In the present work, we construct 28 TM@MoSe2 SACs by loading different TM atoms onto monolayer MoSe2, and first-principle calculations in the framework of density functional theory (DFT) are performed to screen the potential SACs for high-efficiency NRR. Among them, Mn, Os, V@MoSe2 show the most preferable limiting potentials of −0.39 V, −0.36 V, −0.36 V, respectively. The origin of the excellent NRR performances is analyzed and discussed from the aspects of electronic states, kinetics and NN bond length. Furthermore, three independent descriptors of φ, integrated Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (ICOHP) and Δ G * N are adopted to describe the NRR activity trend of TM@MoSe2 SACs. 2 Computational model and methods All the calculations are performed by spin-polarized DFT employed in Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [44]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional is used to describe the exchange-correlation interactions [45]. The model of TM@MoSe2 SAC consists of a 4 × 4 MoSe2 supercell (with lattice constant of a = b = 13.28 Å) and 28 TM single atoms (Fig. 1a ). A vacuum space of 15 Å along z-direction is added to avoid the influence caused by periodic units. The cutoff energy is set as 420 eV [46], and the Brillouin zone is sampled by 2 × 2 × 1 and denser 5 × 5 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack (MP) grid during structural optimization and electronic properties calculations. During structural optimization, the convergence criteria for energy and force are 10–5 eV and 0.02 eV·Å −1, respectively. The Grimme (DFT + D3) method is used to correct the van der Waals interactions [47]. Bader charge analysis was used to evaluate the atomic charge transfer [48–50]. The Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (COHP) method was further employed to investigate the nature of bonding and antibonding states, as implemented by the LOBSTER code [51–53]. The diffusion pathways were investigated by using the climbing image nudged elastic band method (CI-NEB) [54]. The Gibbs free energy variation is calculated based on the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model as follows: (1) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E ZPE − T Δ S + n 1 · eU + Δ G pH in which Δ E , Δ E ZPE , Δ S represent the difference of total energy, zero-point energy, entropy between reactant and product at T =298.15 K. n 1 and U are the number of transferred electrons and the applied electrode potential, respectively. Δ G pH = 2.303 × k B T × pH is the free energy correction of pH with a given value of 0 for an acid environment. In this work. Δ G are obtained from frequency analysis using the VASPKIT code [55]. The catalytic activity of NRR is theoretically evaluated by limiting potential ( U L ), which is defined as U L = − Δ G max / e , in which Δ G max is the free energy barrier of the potential determining step (PDS). The binding energy ( E bin ) and the formation energy ( E for ) are respectively defined as (2) E bin = E TM @ MoSe 2 − E MoSe 2 − E TM (3) E for = E bin − E coh = E TM @ MoSe 2 − E MoSe 2 − E TM , bulk / n 2 in which E TM @ MoSe 2 , E MoSe 2 , E TM , and E TM , bulk represent the total energy of TM@MoSe2 SAC, MoSe2 substrate, isolated TM atom, and TM atom in bulks, respectively. n 2 represents the number of metal atoms per unit cell. Moreover, the electrochemical stability is evaluated by dissolution potential ( U diss ) as (4) U diss = U diss ( TM ) o − E for / n 3 · e in which U diss ( TM ) o and n 3 · e represent the standard dissolution potential of TM atoms and the number of electrons during the dissolution of TM atoms. Accordingly, a SAC candidate is deemed electrochemically stable under acidic conditions if U diss > 0 V vs. SHE. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Pre-screening the stable anchoring site of TM on MoSe2 Fig. 1b shows the two possible anchoring sites of 2D MoSe2 , the hollow site of Se3 and the Mo top site. Prior to the screening, the anchoring stability of 28 TM atoms at these two sites is evaluated by E bin . As illustrated in Fig. 1c and Table S1, all the 56 configurations have negative E bin values from −0.38 eV to −13.26 eV, suggesting that 2D MoSe2 is suitable for anchoring TM atoms. Interestingly, for the TM atoms in a given row, such as, Sc-Zn, Y-Cd, Hf-Hg, the E bin value changes in a V-shaped trend, which might be due to the moderate number of d-electron as well as the half-filled d-orbital of Mn, Nb and Re. It's worth noting that the 9 TM atoms (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Zr, Ag, Re, Au) anchoring on the hollow sites of MoSe2 have more negative E bin than on the Mo top sites, and vice versa for the other 19 TM atoms, indicating the 9 and 19 TM atoms prefer to anchor on the hollow and Mo top sites, respectively. Theoretically, all the preferred anchoring sites should be considered, however, this will lead to amounts of computational cost and workload. According to previous computational studies, the early (later) metals with nearly empty (filled) d-orbital electrons have relatively poor NRR activity with respect to the TM atoms with nearly half-filled d-orbitals [56–58]. The most of the hollow site-preferred TM atoms (including Sc, Ti, V, Zr, Ag, Au) belong to the early or later metals, hence they may have relatively poor NRR activity, which is tenable to be put aside in further screening procedure. Therefore, the majority anchoring sites, i.e. TM atoms on the Mo top sites, are selected as the typical representatives, which can give persuasive and convincing results for the clarification of the NRR catalytic activity. Besides, the same TM anchoring sites are conducive to the comparison of electronic structure properties of TM@SACs. Moreover, the research methodology of the majority anchoring sites of TM @MoSe2 can also be applied in the hollow preferred sites. Herein, although there are 19 TM atoms on the Mo top sites have more negative E bin values than the 9 TM atoms on the hollow sites, the total 28 TM atoms on the Mo top sites are stable existed with negative E bin . Therefore, the total 28 TM atoms on the Mo top sites are investigated in the subsequent context. 3.2 Screening the potential TM@MoSe2 SAC 3.2.1 The screening scheme A strict and reliable screening process [56,59,19] is proposed to pick out the excellent TM@MoSe2 SAC according to the following criteria Fig. 2 ): ((1) thermodynamically and electrochemical stability of TM@MoSe2 ( E for < 0, U diss > 0 ), (2) efficient adsorption of N2 on TM@MoSe2 ( Δ G * N 2 < 0), (3) superior to the poisonous HER ( Δ G * H − Δ G * N 2 > 0), (4) stabilization of *NNH ( Δ G * NNH − Δ G * N 2 < 0.5 eV), (5) destabilization of *NH2 ( Δ G * NH 3 − Δ G * NH 2 < 0.5 eV) and (6) outstanding limiting potential ( U L > −0.4 V). 3.2.2 Stability of TM@MoSe2 The clustering and the dissolution of TM atoms under electric potential will greatly affect the stability of SAC. To this end, E for and U diss of 28 SACs are calculated to evaluate the thermodynamic and electrochemical stability of TM@MoSe2, respectively. The calculated results summarized in Fig. 3a show that Mn, Nb, Re, Fe, Cr, W, Pd, Ni, Mo, Os, Rh@MoSe2 meet the criteria of E for < 0 and U diss > 0 simultaneously, which indicates that these 12 SACs are thermodynamic and electrochemical stable. V, Ta, Co, Hg@MoSe2 are quasi-stable because they are located near the border of stability and instability. While the other 13 SACs are thermodynamic or electrochemical unstable and will be abandoned in the next screening process. 3.2.3 Adsorption of N2 on TM@MoSe2 The effective adsorption and activation of N2 is crucial to the NRR process, but it is also challenging due to the extremely strong NN bond. As displayed in Fig. 3b, the adsorption of N2 includes physical and chemical ones. Considering the weak physical adsorption, only two chemical adsorption configurations are discussed in this work: end-on and side-on patterns. The calculated adsorption free energies of N2 on 15 TM@MoSe2 are summarized in Fig. 3c and Table S2. According to the criterion of Δ G * N 2 < 0, Pd, Hg@MoSe2 are further abandoned owing to the positive Δ G * N 2 in both end-on and side-on configurations. Accordingly, the more stable adsorption configurations (End-on for Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Rh, Re Os@MoSe2, while Side-on for V, Nb, Mo, Ta, W@MoSe2) are considered for the subsequent screening process. 3.2.4 NRR selectivity of TM@MoSe2 In the electrochemical environment, the reaction activity of NRR will be greatly impeded by the competition reaction of HER if a large number of H+ directly attack the catalyst surface, instead of adsorbed N2 [60]. In addition, the Volmer step of HER will convert H+/e− into *H, which will cover the active site and hinder the adsorption of N2 [6]. Herein, we evaluate the selectivity of NRR by comparing the adsorption free energies of *N2 ( Δ G * N 2 ) and *H ( Δ G * H ) on TM@MoSe2. A positive (negative) value of Δ G * H − Δ G * N 2 indicate high (low) NRR selectivity. As depicted in Fig. 4a and Table S3, Rh@MoSe2 is abandoned for the more negative Δ G * H . While V, W, Ta, Co, Ni, Cr, Os, Re, Nb, Mo, Mn, Fe @MoSe2 exhibit high NRR selectivity with Δ G * H − Δ G * N 2 > 0 , and they can enter the following screening. 3.2.5 NRR activity of TM@MoSe2 As schematically shown in Fig. 5 , NRR generally proceeds through four pathways: distal, alternating pathway through the end-on configuration and enzymatic, consecutive pathway through the side-on configuration. According to the previous report, the first (*N2+H++e−→*NNH) and the last (*NH2+H++e−→*NH3) proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) steps are promising to be the PDS of NRR. Therefore, the free energy variations of these two steps are deemed as the descriptors to initially evaluate the activity of TM@MoSe2. As shown in Fig. 4b and Table S4, 5 TM@MoSe2 (TM= V, Mo, Cr, Mn, Os) meet the criteria of Δ G * NNH − Δ G * N 2 < 0.5 eV and Δ G * NH 3 − Δ G * NH 2 < 0.5 eV simultaneously, so they are preliminarily deemed as potential candidates with high NRR activity. Moreover, as an important indicator of NRR activity, the limiting potential ( U L ) describes the minimum energy required in the whole NRR process. The U L of TM@MoSe2 SACs along different paths are summarized in Fig. 6a . The criteria of U L > −0.4 V is satisfied along three reaction paths: the distal path for Mn, Os@MoSe2 and the consecutive path for V@MoSe2, with the favorable U L of −0.39 V, −0.36 V, −0.36 V, respectively. The free energy variations along these three paths are displayed in Figs. 6b-d. 3.3 Typical SACs for NRR-Mn, Os, V@MoSe2 3.3.1 Electronic properties In the NRR process, N2 is activated through the “σ-donation and π* back-donation” [1] (Fig. 7a ). That is, the empty orbitals of TM receive lone pair electrons from N2, and simultaneously donate the partial d-orbital electrons back to the antibonding orbitals of N2. As a result, the inert NN bond is weakened, and N2 is activated. Fig. 7b-d depict the differential charge density of Mn, Os, V@MoSe2, the electrons are gained and lost at both the reactive site and N2, indicating the bi-directional electron transfer between the TM atom and N2. Bader charge analysis indicates that 0.46 e−, 0.64 e−, 0.76 e− are transferred from Mn, Os, V@MoSe2 to N2, respectively, which activates N2 well and promotes the subsequent hydrogenation. Figs. 8b -d shows the partial density of states (PDOS) of Mn, Os, V@MoSe2, respectively. The p orbital of N2 and the d orbital of TM atoms are remarkably overlapped. As compared with the free N2, the bonding orbitals (σ, σ*, π) of adsorbed N2 approach the Fermi level, and are strongly hybridized with the d orbital of TM atoms at around −6 eV, resulting in greatly enhanced adsorption of N2. Moreover, due to the existence of “π* back-donation”, the π* antibonding orbital of N2 is split and overlapped with the d orbital near the Fermi level. The occupied d-π* orbital below the Fermi level can further enhance the adsorption of N2, while the unoccupied d-π* orbital above the Fermi level can activate N2 and promote the subsequent hydrogenation. Fig. 9a illustrates the charge transfer of each part of TM@MoSe2 SAC in the NRR process, in which the SAC system is divided into three moieties, MoSe2 substrate, the catalytic active center of TM-Se3 and the NxHy intermediates. Fig. 9b-d plots the charge variation during NRR process of Os-distal, Mn-distal and V-consecutive, respectively. Evidently, A large number of electrons are transferred from the MoSe2 substrate (moiety 1) to the center of TM-Se3 active center (moiety 2) and NxHy intermediates (moiety 3) in all three pathways. Noticeably, in the V-consecutive pathway, the charge variation of the V-Se3 active site is very small, which can be considered as the electronic transmitter between the substrate and the adsorbates. 3.3.2 Diffusion barriers and kinetic stability Kinetic stability is crucial to the feasibility of experimental preparation [61]. As displayed in Fig. 10a , two diffusion paths of TM on MoSe2 are considered: (1) from one Mo top site to another Mo top site, (2) from one Mo top site to the hollow site. Fig. 10b summarizes the diffusion barriers of Mn, Os, V@MoSe2. With respect to the limiting potentials of 0.39 eV, 0.36 eV, 0.36 eV in Mn, Os, V@MoSe2, respectively, the diffusion barriers are much higher (0.97 eV-2.44 eV). It means that the energy supplied by the applied potential is not enough for the TM atom to diffuse, suggesting kinetic stability and the feasibility of experimental preparation. Figs. S1 depicts the atomic structures of Mn, Os, V@MoSe2 along different diffusion paths. 3.3.3 Evaluation of N2 activation by nn bond length Fig. 11a summarizes the variation of NN bond length ( Δ d N ≡ N ) in the optimized intermediates along Mn-distal, Os-distal and V-consecutive paths (Fig. S2a-c). The d N ≡ N values along any path increase gradually, which promotes the activation of inert N2 and facilitates the adsorption of H+. Specifically, the d N ≡ N value is elongated to 1.309 Å and 1.314 Å of *NNHH intermediates along the Mn, Os-distal paths in end-on configuration, respectively. While the d N ≡ N value is prominently elongated to 1.412 Å along the V-consecutive path in side-on configuration, which can be attributed to the two N atoms bonding with the V atom, as well as more charge transfer between TM atom and the adsorbed N2 (Fig. 7b-d). However, too-strong adsorption is detrimental to hydrogenation, and too-weak adsorption makes the intermediates easy to desorb. As shown in Fig. 11b-d, the adsorption free energies of *N2, *NNH, and *NNHH are negatively correlated with the Δ d N ≡ N values. So Δ d N ≡ N can be adopted as a descriptor to estimate the activation degree of N2, but it is not enough to predict the NRR performances. Therefore, it is urgent to find universal descriptors to comprehensively evaluate the NRR performances on TM@MoSe2. 3.4 Three descriptors of TM@MoSe2 for NRR 3.4.1 Universal descriptor φ For some electrochemical reactions, such as NRR, CO2RR, OER/ORR, the catalytic activity is closely related to the appropriate adsorption strength between the reactant and intermediates. It's well known that the adsorption of N2 is the first and one of the most challenging steps in NRR, which is greatly correlated with the electronic properties of catalysts. While the electronic structures are dramatically affected by the number of d electrons (Nd) and electronegativity of TM atoms, coordination number and electronegativity of coordination atoms. Xu et al. found that the NRR catalytic activity of graphene-based SACs is tightly correlated with the coordination number of TM atoms and the electronegativity of the nearest neighbor atoms [11]. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a universal descriptor to evaluate the adsorption strength of intermediates and the electronic structures. Chen et al. proposed a universal descriptor φ, of which the intrinsic properties are combined to assess the NRR activity of N-doped boron phosphide [56]. Herein, a modified universal descriptor φ is proposed to evaluate the adsorption and activation of N2 on TM@MoSe2 SAC: φ = θ d × ( x TM + n Se · x Se ) ( n Se + 1 ) x Se in which θ d and x TM represent the number of valence electrons and electronegativity of TM atoms, respectively; x Se is the electronegativity of Se, n Se is the number of Se atoms in the substrate. The relationship of the adsorption free energy of N2 and φ ( Δ G * N 2 ∼ φ) is explored and portrayed as volcano-like plots in Figs. 12a -b. The top of the volcano plot is located at φ ≈ 6 and φ ≈5 in the end-on and the side-on patterns, respectively. The TM@MoSe2 with moderate φ values have stronger adsorption of N2, specifically, the N2 adsorbed on the V, Cr, Mn, Nb, Mo, Ta, W, Re atoms via end-on patterns and on the Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, W atoms via side-on patterns, respectively, as shown in the shaded green area in Figs. 12a-b. Therefore, as a universal descriptor, φ can be used to evaluate the adsorption capacity of N2 on SAC through some simple intrinsic parameters. 3.4.2 Crystal orbital Hamilton population and the adsorption strength of *N The bonding strength of *N on metal surface is of great importance to the activity of NH3 synthesis. The previous researches have reported the bonding strength of *N-TM of catalysts from the viewpoints of thermodynamic [62,63] and electronic properties [18,22,56], which can be quantitatively described by the binding energy and ICOHP of *N-TM, respectively. According to the research of Nørskov and coworkers, the moderate binding strength of *N on the pure TM surface has the relative higher NRR activity. Therefore, exploring the relationship of ICOHP ∼ φ is meaningful to estimate the NRR catalytic activity based on the electronic structure calculation. As displayed in Fig. S3, for a given row in periodic table of chemical elements, as the number of d electrons increases, both the bonding and antibonding orbitals move downward firstly and then upward. It is worth noting that the adsorption strength of *N will be greatly weakened if the antibonding orbital is below the Fermi level but opposite for the bonding states. The ICOHP is an appropriate descriptor for quantitively assessing the bonding strength of *N on TM@MoSe2. Interestingly, the ICOHP value decreases firstly and then increases, suggesting that TM@MoSe2 with nearly half-filled d-orbital can stably adsorb *N species. As plotted in Fig. 12c, the scaling relationship exists between ICOHP and adsorption energy of *N ( Δ E * N ) with R2=0.85. Thus, the ICOHP can be used as a descriptor to assess the adsorption ability of intermediates. As shown in Fig. 12d, the ICOHP has a volcanic-like relationship with φ, where the most negative ICOHP appears at φ ≈ 6. It can be concluded that the TM atoms with moderate φ values in the shaded green area show relatively stronger bonding strength of *N. 3.4.3 Scaling relationship and volcano plot It is important to figure out the association between each elementary step of NRR. On the closely-packed and stepped transition-metal surfaces, the adsorption energy of NH x (x = 1, 2, 3) is linearly scaled with that of the central N atom, and the scaling constant depends on x [64]. In the side-on configuration, two N atoms are bonded with the TM atom, but in the end-on configuration, only one N atom is bonded with the TM atom, and the distal path has a more favorable U L than the alternating path in most cases (Fig. 6a). Therefore, the distal path is selected to investigate the scaling relationships between each step of NRR. As shown in Fig. S4, the free energy change at each step scales linearly with the adsorption energy of *N ( Δ G * N ). Accordingly, Fig. 13 shows the volcano plot between Δ G * N and the limiting potential, of which each line corresponds to an elementary step. As expected, the first and the last PCET step (solid red and purple lines, respectively) are most likely to become PDS. Cr, Mn, Os@MoSe2 are near the top of the volcano, which is consistent with the above screening process. 3.5 The discussion about experimental fabrication of Mn, Os, V@MoSe2 According to the above screening results, Mn, Os, V@MoSe2 SACs are predicted to be superior NRR catalysts with great structural stability, NRR selectivity and activity. However, to the best of our knowledge, there is no relevant literature on experimental preparation of Mn, Os, V @MoSe2 SACs that has been reported up to now. Inspiringly, on the basis of the system engineering concept, Zhang and coworkers fabricated a Mn-doped MoS2 ultrathin nanosheet anchoring on a fin-tube-like hierarchical carbon skeleton vertically to achieve the synergistic optimization of intrinsic activity and electrode architecture [65]. Robertson and coworkers have successfully observed and verified the substitution of the V single atom for Mo in CVD grown MoS2 monolayer by a combination of annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (ADF-STEM) and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) mapping [66]. Since the structure of MoSe2 is very similar to that of MoS2, we think that these methods are very instructive for the fabrication of Mn, V@MoSe2. While for the preparation of Os@MoSe2, we have not found any experimental reports related to Os SAC, which may be attributed to the rarity of Os element on earth. Therefore, we believe that Mn, V@MoSe2 SACs are hopefully to be fabricated in the near future. 4 Conclusion In summary, by means of DFT calculations and a reliable screening process, we systematically investigated the potential of a single transition metal atom loaded on the MoSe2 monolayer (TM@MoSe2) as the potential NRR electrocatalyst. According to the six-step screening in terms of stability, N2 adsorption, NRR selectivity and activity, Mn, Os, V@MoSe2 are efficiently selected out from 28 candidates as promising SACs for the NRR, with favorable U L of −0.39 V, −0.36 V and −0.36 V, respectively. The electronic properties are then comprehensively discussed to reveal the catalytic origin of Mn, Os, V@MoSe2. The kinetic stability, as well as the activation degree of N2 are also evaluated by the diffusion barriers of TM and the bond length of NN, respectively. Subsequently, aiming at three key processes of NRR (adsorption and activation of N2, adsorption strength of intermediates on TM@MoSe2, and the limiting potential), three independent descriptors (φ, ICOHP, Δ G * N ) are put forward to reveal the activity trends and establish a panoramic picture of NRR. coredata.dc:description: Two-dimensional single-atom catalysts (2D SACs) have attracted much more attention in the field of ammonia synthesis via electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR). In this work, we comprehensively study the NRR performance of 28 transition metals SACs loaded on 2D MoSe2 using density functional theory calculations. In view of thermodynamics and electrochemical stability, adsorption of N2, selectivity and activity of NRR, Mn, Os, V@MoSe2 exhibit outstanding performances with the most favorable potentials of -0.39 V, -0.36 V and -0.36 V, respectively. The excellent NRR performances are comprehensively related to the electronic states, kinetics, and NN bond length. Furthermore, aiming at three vital processes of NRR (adsorption and activation of N2, adsorption strength of intermediates, and the limiting potential), three independent descriptors (φ, ICOHP, Δ G * N ) are adopted to make the activity trend clear. The results are of guiding significance to the design of high-efficiency NRR using SAC.
coredata.dc:title: Screening of single-atom catalysts of transition metal supported on MoSe2 for high-efficiency nitrogen reduction reaction
